qas.question: When did people lobby for allowing more than one category to be selected on legal forms?
How did the public react to the categories of "bi-racial" and "multiracial"?
Which political leaders spoke out against the proposed designations?

answers.text: Senator Diane Watson and Representative Augustus Hawkins

qas.question: What did they fear would happen?

answers.text: a loss in political and economic power

qas.question: Who lobbied for the ability to show more than one ethnic category on legal forms before the 1980s?

plausible_answers.text: the addition of the category of "bi-racial" or "multiracial"

qas.question: What did the U.S. government propose that people were happy about?
What year did the U.S. government propose getting rid of a multiracial category?
What politician was in favor of the multiracial category?
Who would gain power from abandoning their one category?

context: By <a0_0>the 1980s<a0_0/>, <b4_0>parents of mixed-race children<b4_0/> (and adults of mixed-race ancestry) began to organize and lobby for the ability to show more than one ethnic category on Census and other legal forms. They refused to be put into just one category. When the U.S. government proposed <b5_0>the addition of the category of "bi-racial" or "multiracial"<b5_0/> in <b6_0>1988<b6_0/>, the response from the general public was <a1_0>mostly negative<a1_0/>. Some African-American organizations and political leaders, such as <a2_0>Senator <b7_0>Diane Watson<b7_0/> and Representative Augustus Hawkins<a2_0/>, were particularly vocal in their rejection of the category. They feared <a3_0>a loss in political and economic power<a3_0/> if <b8_0>African Americans<b8_0/> abandoned their one category.
